customer_addr:
2976 E. State St Suite 120 #211
Eagle, ID 83616

citations.narrative:
On May 22, a parakeet was killed when a small child stepped on it. The child had been sitting on its mother’s lap on a
bench in the parakeet enclosure and suddenly jump off, landing on the bird which was on floor in front of the bench. The
enclosure is designed to allow the public to come in and have an interactive experience with the parakeets, feeding them
from their hands with seed provided by the facility. There are about 300 parakeets in the enclosure. People are seated on
benches as they feed the birds. Some of the birdseed falls on the floor around the benches or onto people's shoes. The
inspector watched 4 or 5 groups move through the enclosure and there were large numbers of parakeets around people's
feet and perched on shoes in every group. The attendants generally did not attempt to keep the parakeets away from the
benches or people’s feet while they were seated, but they did instruct them to keep their feet and heals on the floor and
shuffle as they walked in out of the enclosure. They did try to shew birds away from one set of small children. Some
people’s feet, especially children, could not completely reach the floor and many people inadvertently lifted the heels of
their shoes and the inspector observed birds putting their heads under the heals looking for seeds.
During public exhibition, care must be taken so that there is minimal risk of harm to the birds with sufficient distance
and/or barriers between the birds and the general viewing public to assure the safety of animals.
To be corrected by: June 6.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.131(c)(1)  Direct
   
Handling of animals. 
On May 22, a parakeet was killed when a small child stepped on it. The child had been sitting on its mother’s lap on a 
bench in the parakeet enclosure and suddenly jump off, landing on the bird which was on floor in front of the bench. The 
enclosure is designed to allow the public to come in and have an interactive experience with the parakeets, feeding them 
from their hands with seed provided by the facility. There are about 300 parakeets in the enclosure. People are seated on 
benches as they feed the birds. Some of the birdseed falls on the floor around the benches or onto people's shoes. The 
inspector watched 4 or 5 groups move through the enclosure and there were large numbers of parakeets around people's 
feet and perched on shoes in every group. The attendants generally did not attempt to keep the parakeets away from the 
benches or people’s feet while they were seated, but they did instruct them to keep their feet and heals on the floor and 
shuffle as they walked in out of the enclosure. They did try to shew birds away from one set of small children. Some 
people’s feet, especially children, could not completely reach the floor and many people inadvertently lifted the heels of 
their shoes and the inspector observed birds putting their heads under the heals looking for seeds. 
During public exhibition, care must be taken so that there is minimal risk of harm to the birds with sufficient distance 
and/or barriers between the birds and the general viewing public to assure the safety of animals.  
To be corrected by: June 6. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
